Wood, Black Majority: Negroes in South Carolina from 1670 through the Stono Rebellion

Animating Questions/Argument:

Question: What are the “Southern roots” of Black Americans? What is the colonial African American history?

His key argument is that the role of enslaved Black folks in South Carolina has been largely downplayed because of the ultimate triumph of slavery. Wood says, however, “the Negro majority, through persistent and varied resistance to the constraints of the slave system, brought South Carolina closer to the edge of upheaval than historians have been willing to concede.” – though they inspired a counterattack that sought to further circumscribe the lives of enslaved Black people in the wake of Stono.1)

Contribution to the Field:

This book is incredibly foundational. Along with Morgan writing the next year, Wood is part of an initial wave of scholarship taking the history of slavery more seriously to focus on enslaved people and slavery, itself, rather than accepting it as something of a static historical fact. It's worth considering this as a response to pretty unabashedly racist histories like those of U.B. Phillips.
